But, I thought I'd talk a little bit
about belief, because in some ways
it's a dirty word. You know, William James
wrote this essay on the will to believe.
I think it was one of his Gifford
lectures he gave at the University
of Edinburgh on the philosophy of
religion and the immortality of the soul.
But what he had to argue was that it's
OK to believe, because in his day there
were very vociferous academics who were
saying it's a sin to believe in
something without adequate evidence. It
is an intellectual sin. If you don't have
evidence for something just admit you
don't know. You
know, there's a lot of merit to that
argument, there really is. I'd say I
subscribe to that argument more than I
do not subscribe to it. I can speak, I
think, on behalf of the community of
people working in the field of
parapsychology, they subscribe to it too.
Parapsychologists are, by and large,
committed to the scientific method. That
means that they're looking for evidence
to support theories and hypotheses
related to the existence of psychic
functioning. It's not a matter of belief
for these researchers who pay enormous
attention to the fine points of
methodology. But, to the skeptics -
and they're not real skeptics as I've
pointed out many times - to the scoffers,
they don't want to acknowledge that
there is any possibility of paranormal
phenomena, what we call paranormal. As
far as I can tell it's so widely
distributed in the population that it's
really quite normal. But its called
paranormal because given the paradigm of
the Western materialistic mindset it's
almost impossible to explain. How can we
know the future when the future hasn't
happened, for example? How can we know
about the details of events that take
place far, far away from any sensory
input that could come to us, it seems
illogical, it seems as if it doesn't make
sense. And yes, it doesn't make sense
in terms of the normal senses. So, there
is a tradition in philosophy that you
just don't believe in these things. But,
there's an irony because I think that
tradition largely goes back to an
authentic skeptical philosopher David Hume, who was
a 17th or 18th century empiricist, in the
British tradition, a Scottish philosopher.
He wrote
that if anybody claims that they have
witnessed the miraculous it's safe to
just disbelieve them because miracles
don't happen. It's much safer to
disbelieve them than to accept them. In
fact, he would say, you know,
miracles don't happen, that's sort of the
bedrock of his whole philosophy. So,
people who consider themselves, I think
sometimes are called naturalistic
philosophers, they would say that
anyone who purports to believe in
miracles, meaning what we call the
paranormal or extrasensory perception,
telepathy, precognition, clairvoyance,
psychokinesis, reincarnation, life
after death, all of those things are just
ruled out automatically. You don't even
have to bother with the empirical
evidence, with the fine points of
methodology. They are impossible, we can
discount them because we are naturali
sts. The universe is based on natural
law, the universe is based on rational
principles and anything, any other claims
to the contrary can be safely ignored.
Now, the irony here is that David Hume
was a regular church goer. In spite of his
skepticism
he found it prudent to attend, I think it
was the Scottish Presbyterian Church,
every Sunday.
Now, William James, in his essay on "The
Will to Believe" took issue with these
people who said that belief
in things for which you have no
evidence is an intellectual sin.
William James argued along many
different lines here. In fact, he also
challenged the so-called Pascal's Wager.
Blaise Pascal, the 17th century French
philosopher said, "Life is a wager.
We are wagering our life, our immortal
soul on
whether or not God exists. If we claim God
doesn't exist and we are correct, no
problem. If we claim God does exist
and we're wrong, well, there's no fault really,
so when we die we'll be dead. But, if we
claim God doesn't exist but God
does exist we may be doomed to eternal
damnation.
Therefore, the safest bet is the bet that
God exists, so we should show up in
church." And in that case, in France, it was
the Catholic Church, it was the Mass, it
was the rituals of the Catholic Church.
William James pointed out that that
argument would seem pretty silly to
somebody who wasn't a Catholic, for whom
the option of becoming a devout Catholic
wasn't even in the cards. Say if you're
born a Hindu or a Muslim. But, James
argued further that the idea of
believing in God in order to win a wager
and save your soul from eternal
damnation wasn't very good motivation in
any case. But, he did argue that believing
in religion in this case could be a
very positive thing. He said it's like..
suppose you have a friend and you want
to know, does my friend like me? Well,
won't it be the case that your friend is
going to like you more if you like him back?
If you think about your friend, if you do
things for your friend, if you're a good
friend to your friend, your friend might
like you more. But if you completely
ignore your friend, if you act as if your
friend doesn't even exist, why should
your friend like you? He seemed to be
suggesting that we have the power of
entering into a personal relationship
with the divine. And of course, many
religious traditions say as much.
That it's OK to have that belief, that it's
a good thing to have that belief if it
helps you enter into that kind of relat
ionship. And I think James,
as a pragmatist, would say if your life
is working better because of that
relationshipâ€¦ and I think it's fair
to say that there are all kinds of
people out there who believe they
are having an intimate relationship
with God and that that could be harmful
for them. For example, there are
people who commit crimes in the name of
God, including murder. So, I think James
has a point. I don't really
wholeheartedly agree because it seems to
me first of all God doesn't care all that
much whether you believe in God.
I'm thinking back to my own
experiences because I've had an intimate
relationship, I think of it as maybe with
the universe, with the consciousness of
the universe.
I've been guided by dreams
and synchronicities throughout my life. I've
been open to them. I've been willing to
believe in the possibility that my
psyche, my consciousness can do these
things. I believe in myself in that
regard. In parapsychology we have a
whole set of research known as the sheep-
goat effect which basically says that
people who believe they can do ESP,
perform better than people who believe
they can't on tests of ESP.
It's that simple. Belief does play a role. I
want to conclude with one thought from
my mentor, Arthur M. Young, the inventor of
the Bell helicopter. He once said to me,
"Belief is like the flywheel of an engine."
You know, a flywheel, it basically
stores rotational energy, it spins around.
The engine doesn't have constant
rotational energy because you take your
foot on and off the gas. When you put
your foot on the gasâ€¦
vroom. But if your foot isn't on the gas
the engine slows down. But the
flywheel is what keeps that rotational
energy going. It keeps your engine going.
Arthur Young said, "Belief works just
like that. It keeps you going when you're
not getting power from any other source,
it's your belief that keeps you moving
forward." So, I would say this, belief
serves a positive psychological function.
Or, let me put it even a little more
conservatively: belief can serve a
positive psychological function. But,
frankly, I'm willing to concede along
with all those intellectual skeptics
that oftentimes a great deal of harm
occurs when belief is misplaced. And I
think you would all agree with me about
that.
So, the question I'll leave
you with today is: What do you
believe in? What do you believe in? What
are your core beliefs? Are there any
of your core beliefs that you would be
willing to let go of? Is there anything
that maybe you believe in a little too
much? I'll leave you with that thought.
Thank you, thank you, for being with
me.
